description:
Umbelopsis ramanniana AG is a species of fungus belonging to the Mucoromycota phylum, specifically the Umbelopsidaceae family. It is a saprobic organism, meaning it derives its nutrients from decomposing organic matter in the environment.

This fungus is commonly found in soil, decaying plant material, and the rhizosphere (the zone of soil surrounding plant roots). It is known to play a role in the decomposition of cellulose and other plant-derived compounds, contributing to nutrient cycling in terrestrial ecosystems.

Umbelopsis ramanniana AG reproduces asexually through the formation of sporangiospores, which are dispersed by air currents or water. The fungus exhibits a distinctive branching pattern in its mycelium, which can help in its identification.

Taxonomically, this species was first described by the German mycologist Adolf Gaston Edmond Ramann in 1928, and the "AG" in its name refers to the author's initials.
